facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 301 of 1958 was filed by special leave from the judgment and order dated February 21, 1958, of the Madhya Pradesh High Court.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 301 of 1958. Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated February 21, 1958, of the Madhya Pradesh High Court at Jabalpur in Letters Patent Appeal No. 22 of 1958, against the order dated February 20, 1958, of the said High Court in Misc. Petition No. 266 of 1957.

facts.text: The second appellant is the Municipal Committee of Dhamtari constituted under the C. P. and Berar Municipalities Act, 1922.

anchor.surface_text: The second appellant is the Municipal Committee of Dhamtari constituted under the C. P. and Berar Municipalities Act, 1922 (Act 11 of 1922) and the first appellant is its President having been elected as such on July 10, 1956.

facts.text: The first appellant was elected as President on July 10, 1956, and assumed charge on July 27, 1956.

anchor.surface_text: and the first appellant is its President having been elected as such on July 10, 1956. He assumed charge of his office as President on July 27, 1956. It may be mentioned that he was returned as a Congress candidate but has since been expelled from that party for having contested the last general election as an independent candidate against the Congress candidate.

facts.text: First appellant was returned as a Congress candidate but expelled for contesting as independent.

anchor.surface_text: It may be mentioned that he was returned as a Congress candidate but has since been expelled from that party for having contested the last general election as an independent candidate against the Congress candidate. It appears that there are two factions in the Municipal Committee.

facts.text: Dhurmal Daga, a Congress member, allegedly imported cloth without paying octroi duty on August 7, 1956.

anchor.surface_text: The first appellant alleges that one Dhurmal Daga, a member of the committee belonging to the Congress party was on August 7, 1956, detected importing within the municipal limits certain cloth without paying the octroi duty.

facts.text: Dhurmal Daga alleged grave mismanagement by first appellant and went on hunger strike.

anchor.surface_text: Dhurmal Daga, on the other hand, alleged that the first appellant was guilty of grave mismanagement of the affairs of the Municipal Committee and went on hunger strike for securing the appointment of a committee to enquire into the misconduct of the first appellant.

facts.text: Leaflets containing demands and charges were widely distributed.

anchor.surface_text: Copies of the leaflets containing the demands and charges which are said to have been widely distributed are annexures I and II to the present petition.

facts.text: Several persons and firms preferred charges against the first appellant.

anchor.surface_text: It appears that several persons and firms also preferred charges against the first appellant, the President of the Municipal Committee.

facts.text: Collector Raipur intervened and persuaded Dhurmal Daga to abandon fast on assurance to look into matter.

anchor.surface_text: The Collector, Raipur, personally intervened and persuaded the said Dhurmal Daga to abandon the fast on an assurance that he would look into the matter.

facts.text: Collector deputed Shri N. R. Rana, Additional Deputy Collector, to enquire into complaints.

anchor.surface_text: The Collector deputed one Shri N. R. Rana the Additional Deputy Collector to enquire into the complaints of maladministration of the affairs of the Municipal Committee.

facts.text: Memorandum No. K J N. P. Dhamtari dated August 24, 1956, called for detailed explanation from President.

anchor.surface_text: By a Memorandum No. K J N. P. Dhamtari dated August 24, 1956, the said N. R. Rana called upon the first appellant as the President of the second appellant to give detailed explanation of each complaint, a list of which was enclosed therewith.

facts.text: President submitted detailed report on objections and reply to charges (Annexures IV and V).

anchor.surface_text: Annexures IV and V to the petition are copies of the detailed report on the objections and the reply to the charges made against the Municipal Committee submitted from the office of the Municipal Committee by the first appellant as the President of the Municipal Committee.

facts.text: Additional Deputy Collector held the enquiry; petitioner was present on some occasions.

anchor.surface_text: The Additional Deputy Collector thereafter held the enquiry. The High Court states that it had gone through the materials on which the State Government based its action on enquiry into the charges levelled against the Municipal Committee and that the records of the enquiry showed that on some occasions the petitioner was present during the enquiry.

facts.text: State Government published notification on November 18, 1957, appointing Shri B. P. Jain as Executive Officer for 18 months under s.53-A.

anchor.surface_text: On November 18, 1957, a notification was published in the Official Gazette whereby the State Government, in exercise of the powers conferred on it by s. 53-A of the C. P. Berar Municipalities Act, 1922, appointed one Shri B. P. Jain, the second respondent before us, as the Executive Officer of the Municipal Committee, Dhamtari, for a period of 18 months with certain powers as therein mentioned.

facts.text: Notification listed reasons for incompetency: granted advances without sanction, carelessness in embezzlement, etc. (grounds a-o).

anchor.surface_text: Whereas it appears to the State Government that the Municipal Committee, Dhamtari, has proved itself incompetent to perform the duties imposed on it by or under the Central Provinces and Berar Municipalities Act, 1922 (11 of 1922), inasmuch as it- a granted grain and building advances to the employees without prior sanction and no efforts were made for their recovery, b showed carelessness in cases of embezzlement...

facts.text: Appellants filed writ petition on December 21, 1957, obtained stay on January 11, 1958.

anchor.surface_text: On December 21, 1957, the two appellants before us presented before the Madhya Pradesh High Court the writ petition out of which the present appeal has arisen and on January 11, 1958, obtained an order staying the operation of the order of appointment of the Executive Officer.

facts.text: Writ petition dismissed on February 20, 1958; Letters Patent Appeal dismissed February 21, 1958.

anchor.surface_text: The writ petition was dismissed on February 20, 1958. There was a Letters Patent Appeal which was dismissed in limine on February 21, 1958.

facts.text: Special leave granted by Supreme Court on April 1, 1958; interim stay vacated May 13, 1958.

anchor.surface_text: The application for certificate under Arts. 132 and 133 was refused on March 21, 1958. The present appellants applied for and on April 1, 1958, obtained from this Court special leave to appeal from the judgment of the Madhya Pradesh High Court. The interim stay order made by this Court was eventually vacated on May 13, 1958.

facts.text: High Court went through materials and found records showed petitioner present during enquiry on some occasions; no suggestion of denial of opportunity.

anchor.surface_text: There is no suggestion that the appellants wanted an opportunity to adduce any evidence or were prevented from doing so or that they were in any way hampered in their defence.

facts.text: Rana's report submitted November 22, 1956, forwarded to State Government April 24, 1957.

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Rana, Deputy Collector held an enquiry and called the explanation of the Municipal Committee and its President and submitted his report on November 22, 1956, which was forwarded to the State Government on April 24, 1957.
The application for certificate under Arts. 132 and 133 was refused on March 21, 1958. The present appellants applied for and on April 1, 1958, obtained from this Court special leave
The application for certificate under Arts. 132 and 133 was refused on March 21, 1958. The present appellants applied for and on April 1, 1958, obtained from this Court special leave

CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 301 of 1958. Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated February 21, 1958, of the Madhya Pradesh High Court at Jabalpur in Letters Patent Appeal No. 22 of 1958, against the order dated February 20, 1958, of the said High Court in Misc. Petition No. 266 of 1957.

On November 18, 1957, a notification was published in the Official Gazette whereby the State Government, in exercise of the powers conferred on it by s. 53-A of the C. P. Berar Municipalities Act, 1922, appointed one Shri B. P. Jain,

concepts.interpretation: Court holds that action under s.53A is administrative, not quasi-judicial; distinguishes from s.57; no need for hearing as in s.57(5); temporary measure for improvement.

interpretation_anchor.surface_text: ged that the first appellant was guilty of grave mismanagement of the affairs of the Municipal Committ

concepts.unlisted_description: Power to appoint Executive Officer if committee incompetent and improvement likely.

concepts.interpretation: Distinguished from s.53A; requires reasonable opportunity under sub-s.5; more drastic, leads to dissolution/supersession; court holds notification is under s.53A not s.57.
concepts.unlisted_description: Power to dissolve or supersede incompetent or defaulting committee.

anchor.surface_text: that even if the impugned Notification be held to come within s. 53-A it is still ultra vires since before promulgating it the State Government has committed a breach of the rules of natural justice in not giving any opportunity to the appellants to defend themselves.

concepts.interpretation: Not required for administrative action under s.53A; distinguished from quasi-judicial; fair play observed via prior enquiry by Deputy Collector.

anchor.surface_text: In the writ application, out of which this appeal arises, the principal prayer of the appellants is for a writ in the nature of certiorari for quashing the order passed by the State Government on November 18, 1957. The next prayer which is for a writ of mandamus restraining the respondents from giving effect to the impugned order is clearly consequential on or ancillary to the main prayer.

concepts.interpretation: Lies only against quasi-judicial bodies acting without jurisdiction, excess, natural justice violation, or error on face; not for pure administrative acts like under s.53A.
concepts.unlisted_description: Prerogative writ to quash errors of inferior courts or quasi-judicial bodies.

anchor.surface_text: The law is now well- settled that a writ of certiorari will lie to control such a statutory body if it purports to act without jurisdiction or in excess of it or in violation of the principles of natural justice, or commits any error apparent on the face of the records, provided that, on a true construction of the statute creating such body, it can be said to be a quasi- judicial body entrusted with quasi-judicial functions.

concepts.interpretation: Requires legal authority to determine rights, duty to act judicially (Atkin LJ test); s.53A action is administrative, not quasi-judicial.
concepts.unlisted_description: Distinction from administrative function; duty to act judicially.

anchor.surface_text: Further, s. 53-A contemplates swift action and a judicial hearing may easily frustrate the very purpose contemplated by s. 53-A, for a judicial act will be subject to the powers of superintendence of the superior courts and the operation of the order under s. 53-A may be postponed, as it has been done in this very case, by taking, the matter from court to court until it is set at rest by this Court. In this connection reference may also be made to s. 25-A of the Act which authorises the State Government to require the committee to appoint, inter alia, a Chief Executive Officer.

concepts.interpretation: Similar to s.53A, administrative power to appoint officers without judicial enquiry.

anchor.surface_text: By a Memorandum No. K J N. P. Dhamtari dated August 24, 1956, the said N. R. Rana called upon the first appellant as the President of the second appellant to give detailed explanation of each complaint, a list of which was enclosed therewith.

concepts.interpretation: Opportunity given via memo for explanation and presence at enquiry; no denial of chance to adduce evidence.

interpretation_anchor.surface_text: losures 1444 is annexed to the petition and marked 111. Annexures IV and V to the petition are companyies of the detaile

anchor.surface_text: There was a charge of mala fide made against the State Government founded on the fact that the first appellants leaving the Congress party had resulted in ill-will towards the first appellant of that -party which was the ruling party in the State Government, but as that charge has not been pressed before us nothing further need be said about it.

concepts.interpretation: Alleged but not pressed; no material to sustain.

anchor.surface_text: To say that action to be taken under s. 53-A is an administrative action is not to say that the State Government has not to observe the ordinary rules of fair play. Reference to the observation made by Fortesque J. in Dr. Bentleys case about God asking Adam and Eve whether they had eaten the forbidden fruit appearing in the judgment of Byles J. in Cooper v. The Wandsworth Board of Works is apposite.

concepts.interpretation: Fair play observed; differs from full natural justice hearing for quasi-judicial acts.
concepts.unlisted_label: Rules of Fair Play in Administrative Action
concepts.unlisted_description: Basic opportunity to be heard in admin actions.

anchor.surface_text: Chapter VIII is headed Control . It prescribes the authorities which have the power to control the acts of committees and also lays down the extent of such control and the method of its exercise. Section 52 gives to the Deputy Commissioner the power to examine the proceedings of committees or subcommittees.

concepts.unlisted_description: Deputy Commissioner's power to examine proceedings.

anchor.surface_text: Any executive officer appointed under subsection 1 shall be deemed to be an officer lent to the committee by Government under sub-section 3 of section 25.

issues.text: Whether the impugned notification, though purporting to be under s. 53-A, was in substance and in reality issued under s. 57 of the Act?

anchor.surface_text: Shri M. K. Nambiar, appearing in support of this appeal, urged three points, namely that though the Notification purports to have been made in exercise of the power,, conferred on the State Government by s. 53-A, in substance and in reality it has been made under s. 57 of the Act that if the Notification is held to be one made under s. 57 it is ultra vires

holdings.text: The impugned notification was issued under s. 53-A and not under s. 57 of the Act, as the State Government had the option to choose between the two sections where requirements overlap on incompetency, and abuse of power can evidence incompetency justifying temporary action under s. 53-A.

anchor.surface_text: In my judgment the State Government was well within its rights, in exercise of its option, to take action, under s. 53-A as it has in terms purported to do. To say that because some of the findings amount to abuse of power the State Government must act under s. 57 is to deprive it of its discretion which the Act undoubtedly confers on it. In my view the fact that the impugned notification records, apart from the findings of incompetency, certain findings of abuse of power, does not lead to the conclusion, as contended for the appellants, that the State Government had taken action under s. 57 and not under s. 53-A although, in terms, it says it acted under the last mentioned section.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Textual comparison of ss.53A and 57 shows overlap on incompetency; s.53A temporary and less drastic; state discretion to opt for s.53A even with abuse findings as they indicate incompetency; extensive EO powers expressly contemplated by s.53A without dissolving committee.

holdings.text: Action under s. 53-A is an administrative act, not quasi-judicial, as no duty to act judicially is expressly or impliedly imposed; no lis inter partes, no prescribed procedure like hearing under s.57(5), swift temporary action contemplated.

anchor.surface_text: In the writ application, out of which this appeal arises, the principal prayer of the appellants is for a writ in the nature of certiorari for quashing the order passed by the State Government on November 18, 1957. The law is now well-settled that a writ of certiorari will lie to control such a statutory body if it purports to act without jurisdiction or in excess of it or in violation of the principles of natural justice...

holdings.reasoning_summary: Applies tests from Province of Bombay v. Advani and Atkin LJ definition: legal authority to determine rights + duty to act judicially required; s.53A lacks procedure, subjective elements, contrasts s.57; jurisdictional fact determination not necessarily judicial.

holdings.text: No breach of rules of natural justice under s.53-A, as prior enquiry by Additional Deputy Collector provided opportunity to explain charges, submit replies, and be present; appellants had more than fair play in administrative action.

anchor.surface_text: To say that action to be taken under s. 53-A is an administrative action is not to say that the State Government has not to observe the ordinary rules of fair play... All the charges levelled against the appellants were forwarded to them, and they submitted explanation. The first appellant... attended many of the sittings.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Administrative actions require fair play (opportunity to be heard), not full quasi-judicial hearing; facts show memo issued, explanations submitted (Annex IV-V), presence at enquiry, no denial of evidence adduced.

holdings.text: Writ of certiorari does not lie to quash the notification under s.53-A, as it is purely administrative action not amenable to certiorari which controls only quasi-judicial bodies.

anchor.surface_text: The law is now well- settled that a writ of certiorari will lie to control such a statutory body if it purports to act without jurisdiction or in excess of it or in violation of the principles of natural justice, or commits any error apparent on the face of the records, provided that, on a true construction of the statute creating such body, it can be said to be a quasi- judicial body entrusted with quasi-judicial functions.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Certiorari limited to judicial/quasi-judicial errors (jurisdiction, natural justice, etc.); s.53A administrative per Advani tests; no review of sufficiency of reasons or facts in admin acts.

holdings.text: Charge of mala fides against State Government not sustained.

anchor.surface_text: There was a charge of mala fide made against the State Government founded on the fact that the first appellant leaving the Congress party had resulted in ill-will towards the first appellant of that party which was the ruling party in the State Government, but as that charge has not been pressed before us nothing further need be said about it.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Not pressed in Supreme Court; no material provided.

precedents.citation: Province of Bombay v. Kusaldas S. Advani

anchor.surface_text: In Province of Bombay v. Kusaldas S. Advani this Court has discussed at considerable length the nature of the two kinds of act, judicial and administrative, and has laid down certain tests for ascertaining whether the act of a statutory body is a quasijudicial act or an administrative act. It will, therefore,  1  1950 S.C.R, 621.

precedents.case_name: Province of Bombay v Kusaldas S Advani
precedents.cited_proposition: Nature of judicial and administrative acts and tests to distinguish quasi-judicial from administrative acts

anchor.surface_text: the celebrated definition of a quasi- judicial body given by Atkin L. J. as he then was, in Rex v. Electricity Commissioners and which still holds the field. It runs as follows Whenever any body of persons having legal authority to determine questions affecting rights of subjects, and having the duty to act judicially act in excess of their legal authority they are subject to the controlling jurisdiction of the Kings Bench

precedents.cited_proposition: Definition of quasi-judicial body by Atkin LJ
precedents.cited_holding: Whenever any body of persons having legal authority to determine questions affecting rights of subjects, and having the duty to act judicially act in excess of their legal authority they are subject to the controlling jurisdiction of the Kings Bench

anchor.surface_text: This definition was accepted as correct in Rex v. London Count? Council 2   and many subsequent cases both in England and in this country.

precedents.cited_proposition: Acceptance of Atkin LJ's definition of quasi-judicial body

precedents.citation: R. v. Manchester Legal Aid Committee

anchor.surface_text: Relying on paragraphs 114 and 115 of Halsburys Laws of England, 3rd Edition, Volume 11, at pages 5558 and citing the case of R. v. Manchester Legal Aid Committee 1 , learned counsel for the appellants contends that where a statute requires a decision to be arrived at purely from the point of view of policy or expediency the authority is under no duty to act judicially.

precedents.case_name: R v Manchester Legal Aid Committee
precedents.cited_proposition: Duty to act judicially arises where decision on evidence or opposition, not mere policy

precedents.citation: Province of Bombay v. K. S. Advani

anchor.surface_text: The principles deducible from the various judicial decisions considered by this Court in the Province of Bombay v. K. S. Advani 1 at page 725 were thus formulated, namely that if a statute empowers an authority, not being a Court in the ordinary sense, to decide disputes arising out of a claim made by one party under the statute which claim is opposed by another party and to determine the respective rights of the contesting parties who are opposed to each other, there is a lis and prima facie and in the absence of anything in the statute to the contrary it is the duty of the authority to act judicially and the decision of the authority is a quasi-judicial act

precedents.case_name: Province of Bombay v K S Advani
precedents.cited_proposition: Principles for determining duty to act judicially: lis inter partes or authority vs subject with duty to act judicially

precedents.citation: B. v. Legislative Committee of the Church Assembly

anchor.surface_text: I found support for my opinion on the following passage occurring in the judgment of Lord Hewart C. J. in B. v. Legislative Committee of the Church Assembly 1  In order that a body may satisfy the required test it is not enough that it should have legal authority to determine questions affecting the rights of subjects there must be super-added to that characteristic the further characteristic that the body has the duty to act judicially.

precedents.case_name: R v Legislative Committee of the Church Assembly
precedents.cited_proposition: Duty to act judicially is additional requirement beyond authority to determine rights
precedents.cited_holding: In order that a body may satisfy the required test it is not enough that it should have legal authority to determine questions affecting the rights of subjects there must be super-added... the duty to act judicially

anchor.surface_text: The above passage was quoted with approval by Lord Radcliffe in delivering the judgment of the Privy Council in Nakkuda Alis case I now proceed to apply the principles discussed above to the facts of the present case.

precedents.case_name: Nakkuda Ali v MF de S Jayaratne
precedents.cited_proposition: Approval of requirement of duty to act judicially

anchor.surface_text: Learned counsel for the appellants relied on the case of Capel v. Child 1 . That decision clearly went upon the construction of the statute that came up for consideration. The fact that action could be taken under that statute on affidavits 1 2 Cr. Jr, 558 37 R. R. 761. was construed as a clear indication that the Bishop had to arrive at a decision as to the negligence of the Vicar on hearing evidence adduced before it by affidavit which led to the next conclusion that the Vicar must be given an opportunity of being heard and of adducing evidence in his own defence.

precedents.cited_proposition: Statutory provision for affidavits implies duty to act judicially and give hearing

precedents.citation: Cooper v. The Wandsworth Board of Works

anchor.surface_text: Reference to the observation made by Fortesque J. in Dr. Bentleys case about God asking Adam and Eve whether they had eaten the forbidden fruit appearing in the judgment of Byles J. in Cooper v. The Wandsworth Board of Works 1  is apposite. The decision in the last mentioned case clearly establishes that in some cases it may be necessary to give an opportunity to a party to have his say before an administrative action is taken against him.

precedents.case_name: Cooper v Wandsworth Board of Works
precedents.cited_proposition: Rules of natural justice (fair play) apply to administrative actions, requiring opportunity to be heard

precedents.citation: Westminster Corporation v. London and North Western Railway Co.

anchor.surface_text: per Lord Halsbury L. C. in the Westminster Corporation v. London and North Western Railway Co. 1  . And it cannot on that ground a

precedents.case_name: Westminster Corporation v London and North Western Railway Co
precedents.cited_proposition: Court cannot question exercise of statutory discretion unless abuse of power

precedents.citation: R. v. Manchester Legal Aid Committee

anchor.surface_text: The last two tests were discussed and considered in R. v. Manchester Legal Aid Committee 1 . It is fairly clear to me that tests i to iv are inappropriate in the present case by reason of the provisions in s. 53-A ,as contrasted with s. 57 and other sections of the Act.

precedents.case_name: R v Manchester Legal Aid Committee
precedents.cited_proposition: Tests for duty to act judicially based on policy vs evidence

anchor.surface_text: For reasons stated above I would dismiss this appeal. BHAGWATI J.-I also agree that the appeal should be dismissed with costs but would like to add a few words of my own.

anchor.surface_text: In my judgment the State Government was well within its rights, in exercise of its option, to take action, under s. 53-A as it has in terms purported to do. To say that because some of the findings amount to abuse of power the State Government must act under s. 57 is to deprive it of its discretion which the Act undoubtedly confers on it. In my view the fact that the impugned notification records, apart from the findings of incompetency, certain findings of abuse of power, does not lead to the conclusion, as contended for the appellants, that the State Government had taken action under s. 57 and not under s. 53-A although, in terms, it says it acted under the last mentioned section.
For reasons stated above I would dismiss this appeal. BHAGWATI J.-I also agree that the appeal should be dismissed with costs but would like to add a few words of my own.

anchor.surface_text: In the writ application, out of which this appeal arises, the principal prayer of the appellants is for a writ in the nature of certiorari for quashing the order passed by the State Government on November 18, 1957. The law is now well-settled that a writ of certiorari will lie to control such a statutory body if it purports to act without jurisdiction or in excess of it or in violation of the principles of natural justice...
For reasons stated above I would dismiss this appeal. BHAGWATI J.-I also agree that the appeal should be dismissed with costs but would like to add a few words of my own.

anchor.surface_text: To say that action to be taken under s. 53-A is an administrative action is not to say that the State Government has not to observe the ordinary rules of fair play... All the charges levelled against the appellants were forwarded to them, and they submitted explanation. The first appellant... attended many of the sittings.
For reasons stated above I would dismiss this appeal. BHAGWATI J.-I also agree that the appeal should be dismissed with costs but would like to add a few words of my own.
